text: You can define your own intrinsics using llvmcall. Most of the intrinsics in Julia I can think about boils down to one CPU instruction, do it's useful to just think about them as something intrinsic to the CPU itself, i.e. the lowest level of software.

elements.text: You can define your own intrinsics using llvmcall. Most of the intrinsics in Julia I can think about boils down to one CPU instruction, do it's useful to just think about them as something intrinsic to the CPU itself, i.e. the lowest level of software.

text: You can't define intrinsic functions in julia per definition, you can only define functions. llvm intrinsics are not julia intrinsic functions.

elements.text: You can't define intrinsic functions in julia per definition, you can only define functions. llvm intrinsics are not julia intrinsic functions.

text: Right :sweat_smile: to be more precise: You can use llvmcall to call into LLVMs intrinsics to expand the number of intrinsic functions available from Julia

elements.text: Right
to be more precise: You can use llvmcall to call into LLVMs intrinsics to expand the number of intrinsic functions available from Julia

text: A lot of Julia intrinsics look a lot like llvm intrinsics

elements.text: A lot of Julia intrinsics look a lot like llvm intrinsics

text: You could say `Base.and_int` obviously maps to one. While you could say that's a coincidence, the fact that many acronyms are the same like `Base.fptosi` (FloatingPoint to SignedInteger) suggests mapping to LLVM intrinsics was the intention.

elements.text: You could say
Base.and_int
obviously maps to one. While you could say that's a coincidence, the fact that many acronyms are the same like
Base.fptosi
(FloatingPoint to SignedInteger) suggests mapping to LLVM intrinsics was the intention.

text: I don't know that much about Julia's internals / how it produces LLVM, but it makes sense that at some point you want building blocks that map to intrinsics. The turtles have to stop somewhere.

elements.text: I don't know that much about Julia's internals / how it produces LLVM, but it makes sense that at some point you want building blocks that map to intrinsics. The turtles have to stop somewhere.
